user_message:
Target function code is:
```c
static void
MHD_default_logger_ (void *cls,
                     const char *fm,
                     va_list ap)
{
  vfprintf ((FILE *) cls, fm, ap);
#ifdef _DEBUG
  fflush ((FILE *) cls);
#endif /* _DEBUG */
}
```

List additional symbols that are required to analyze the target function to determine if the target function code violates the following MISRA C rule:
Controlling expressions shall not be invariant. Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
The list will be included in the prompt for the next agent, so be concise and clear.
Explain why each symbol is required in the analysis of the target function for the MISRA C rule.
explanation: To determine whether this function violates the MISRA rule on invariant controlling expressions we must know whether any controlling expressions are actually introduced into the function body (including via preprocessing or macro expansion). _DEBUG: controls whether the fflush call is compiled in — a compile-time constant may change the presence/absence of code and must be known. vfprintf and fflush: these library identifiers can be macros or inline wrappers on some platforms; their definitions/expansions must be inspected to ensure they do not expand into loops or conditionals with invariant controlling expressions that would effectively place such expressions inside this function. FILE and va_list: types used in casts/parameters — their definitions come from the headers and are needed to resolve any macro-based implementations or type-dependent expansions. stdio.h and stdarg.h: header files that provide the declarations/macros for vfprintf/fflush/FILE and va_list; their contents (macro/inline definitions) must be inspected to see if any controlling expressions get introduced by preprocessing or inline expansion.
